response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use an Iterator to iterate over the map and keep track of the current key and value. When you add an object to the map, check if it already exists in the map. If it does, increment its value by 1. If it doesn't, add it with a value of 1. When you iterate over the map with the Iterator, check if the current key is in the map. If it is, increment its value by 1. If it isn't, add it with a value of 1. This way, you can efficiently iterate over the same object however many times its value is.

Explanation: You can use an Iterator to iterate over the map and keep track of the current key and value. When you add an object to the map, check if it already exists in the map. If it does, increment its value by 1. If it doesn't, add it with a value of 1. When you iterate over the map with the Iterator, check if the current key is in the map. If it is, increment its value by 1. If it isn't, add it with a value of 1. This way, you can efficiently iterate over the same object however many times its value is.
